intro: Anadelphia trepidaria, commonly known as the trembling anemone, is a flowering plant native to the temperate regions of the Northern Hemisphere. It belongs to the family Ranunculaceae, which includes buttercups and other similar species. The plant is characterized by its delicate, palmate leaves and showy, white or pale pink flowers that bloom in early spring. It typically grows in moist, shaded environments such as woodland floors and stream banks. Anadelphia trepidaria is known for its ephemeral bloom period, making it a short-lived but visually striking member of its ecosystem.
